elements.name: Hydrogen
elements.description: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek words 'hydro' and 'genes,' meaning 'water-forming,' as hydrogen can react with oxygen to form water.
elements.origin: Primarily produced by the universe's primordial nucleosynthesis and in stars.

elements.name: Helium
elements.description: Helium is the second lightest and second most abundant element in the observable universe.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'helios,' meaning 'sun,' as it was first discovered in the solar spectrum.
elements.origin: Primarily found in natural gas deposits.

elements.name: Lithium
elements.description: Lithium is a soft, silvery-white metal known for its use in batteries.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek word 'lithos,' meaning 'stone,' as it was first discovered in mineral sources.
elements.origin: Primarily found in lithium-containing minerals.

elements.name: Beryllium
elements.description: Beryllium is a lightweight, strong metal often used in aerospace applications.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Arabic word 'buraq' and the Persian word 'burah,' both meaning 'borax.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in borax deposits.

elements.name: Boron
elements.description: Boron is a metalloid with various allotropes, known for its use in borosilicate glass.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Arabic word 'buraq' and the Persian word 'burah,' both meaning 'borax.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in borax deposits.

elements.name: Carbon
elements.description: Carbon is the fundamental building block of organic compounds.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Latin word 'carbo,' meaning 'charcoal.'
elements.origin: Found in various forms, including diamonds, graphite, and organic compounds.

elements.name: Nitrogen
elements.description: Nitrogen is a vital element for life and a major component of Earth's atmosphere.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'nitron' and the Latin word 'nitrum,' both referring to nitrates.
elements.origin: Primarily found in the Earth's atmosphere as nitrogen gas.

elements.name: Oxygen
elements.description: Oxygen is an essential element for life and a key component of the Earth's atmosphere.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek words 'oxy' and 'genes,' meaning 'acid-forming,' due to its role in the formation of acids.
elements.origin: Abundant in the Earth's crust and primarily found as oxides.

elements.name: Fluorine
elements.description: Fluorine is a highly reactive and corrosive halogen gas.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Latin word 'fluere,' meaning 'to flow,' as it was often used in mineral processing.
elements.origin: Primarily found in fluorite and cryolite minerals.

elements.name: Neon
elements.description: Neon is a noble gas known for its use in neon signs.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'neos,' meaning 'new,' due to its recent discovery in comparison to other noble gases.
elements.origin: Found in trace amounts in the Earth's atmosphere.

elements.name: Sodium
elements.description: Sodium is a highly reactive metal used in various industrial applications.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Arabic word 'suda,' meaning 'head of a headache,' referring to the headache-inducing properties of sodium carbonate.
elements.origin: Primarily found in sodium chloride (table salt) deposits.

elements.name: Magnesium
elements.description: Magnesium is an essential element for biological processes and common in minerals.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek region of Magnesia, where magnesium minerals were first discovered.
elements.origin: Primarily found in minerals like magnesite and dolomite.

elements.name: Aluminum
elements.description: Aluminum is a lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal used in various industries.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Latin word 'alumen,' meaning 'bitter salt' or 'alum.'
elements.origin: Primarily found as bauxite, a type of aluminum ore.

elements.name: Silicon
elements.description: Silicon is a metalloid used in electronics and as a building material.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Latin word 'silex' or 'silicis,' meaning 'flint' or 'hard stone.'
elements.origin: Abundant in the Earth's crust and primarily found as silicon dioxide (quartz).

elements.name: Phosphorus
elements.description: Phosphorus is an essential element for life, found in DNA and ATP.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek words 'phos' and 'phoros,' meaning 'light-bringer,' as it can glow in the dark.
elements.origin: Primarily found in phosphate rock deposits.

elements.name: Sulfur
elements.description: Sulfur is an essential element for life, found in amino acids and vitamins.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Latin word 'sulfurium,' meaning 'sulfur.'
elements.origin: Found in various minerals and as native sulfur in volcanic regions.

elements.name: Chlorine
elements.description: Chlorine is a highly reactive and toxic halogen gas.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek word 'chloros,' meaning 'greenish-yellow,' due to its color and properties.
elements.origin: Primarily found in the form of chloride salts.

elements.name: Argon
elements.description: Argon is a noble gas used in various applications, including welding.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek word 'argos,' meaning 'inactive,' due to its lack of reactivity.
elements.origin: Found in trace amounts in the Earth's atmosphere.

elements.name: Potassium
elements.description: Potassium is a highly reactive metal important for biological processes.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the English word 'potash,' referring to the potassium carbonate that was commonly used in soap and glass production.
elements.origin: Primarily found in potash deposits.

elements.name: Calcium
elements.description: Calcium is an essential element for bones, teeth, and various cellular functions.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Latin word 'calx,' meaning 'lime' or 'limestone.'
elements.origin: Abundant in various minerals, including limestone, gypsum, and others.

elements.name: Scandium
elements.description: Scandium is a lightweight and corrosion-resistant metal often used in aerospace applications and high-intensity lamps.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after Scandinavia.
elements.origin: Primarily formed by supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Titanium
elements.description: Titanium is a strong and lightweight metal widely used in aerospace, medical implants, and sports equipment.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after Titans of Greek mythology.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in massive stars through nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Vanadium
elements.description: Vanadium is a transition metal with various industrial applications, including steel production.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after Vanadis (Freya), the Norse goddess of beauty.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae and white dwarf explosions.

elements.name: Chromium
elements.description: Chromium is known for its shiny appearance and is used in stainless steel, plating, and the aerospace industry.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'chroma,' meaning color.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Manganese
elements.discovered_by: Johan Gottlieb Gahn, Carl Wilhelm Scheele
elements.description: Manganese is used in steel production and plays a role in various biological processes.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the region of Magnesia in Greece.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae and white dwarf explosions.

elements.name: Iron
elements.description: Iron is a vital element in the human body and is extensively used in construction and manufacturing.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Old English word 'iren,' meaning metal.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Cobalt
elements.description: Cobalt is used in the production of alloys, magnets, and in the medical field.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the German word 'kobalt,' meaning goblin ore.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Nickel
elements.description: Nickel is used in making coins, batteries, and as an alloying element.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the German word 'kupfernickel,' meaning Devil's copper.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Copper
elements.description: Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and is used in wiring, plumbing, and electronics.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Latin word 'cuprum,' meaning copper.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Zinc
elements.description: Zinc is used in galvanization, batteries, and is an essential trace element for humans.
elements.origin_of_name: The origin of the name 'zinc' is uncertain, but it may come from the German word 'zinke,' meaning spike.
elements.origin: Primarily formed by supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Gallium
elements.description: Gallium is a soft metal used in electronics, semiconductors, and some medical applications.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after 'Gallia,' the Latin name for France.
elements.origin: Primarily formed by cosmic ray spallation in the Earth's crust.

elements.name: Germanium
elements.description: Germanium is used in semiconductors and optical fibers.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after 'Germania,' the Latin name for Germany.
elements.origin: Primarily formed in supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Arsenic
elements.description: Arsenic has a history of use in poison, but also has some semiconductor applications.
elements.origin_of_name: The name 'arsenic' is derived from the Greek word 'arsenikon,' meaning 'yellow orpiment.'
elements.origin: Primarily formed by supernovae nucleosynthesis.

elements.name: Selenium
elements.description: Selenium is used in photovoltaic cells and some electronic applications.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after 'Selene,' the Greek goddess of the moon.
elements.origin: Primarily formed by cosmic ray spallation in the Earth's crust.

elements.name: Bromine
elements.description: Bromine is a halogen used in flame retardants and some pharmaceuticals.
elements.origin_of_name: Named from the Greek 'bromos,' meaning 'stench.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in brine pools and marine sediments.

elements.name: Krypton
elements.description: Krypton is a noble gas used in lighting, lasers, and some diagnostic applications.
elements.origin_of_name: Named from the Greek 'kryptos,' meaning 'hidden.'
elements.origin: Primarily formed through the radioactive decay of isotopes in the Earth's crust.

elements.name: Rubidium
elements.description: Rubidium has applications in atomic clocks and as a research tool in physics.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Latin 'rubidus,' meaning 'deep red,' due to the color of its spectral lines.
elements.origin: Primarily found in lepidolite, pollucite, and other minerals.

elements.name: Strontium
elements.description: Strontium is used in pyrotechnics, medical imaging, and as a stabilizer in fireworks.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Scottish village of Strontian.
elements.origin: Primarily found in celestite and strontianite minerals.

elements.name: Yttrium
elements.description: Yttrium is used in alloys, lasers, and some electronic components.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden.
elements.origin: Primarily found in yttria, xenotime, and monazite minerals.

elements.name: Zirconium
elements.description: Zirconium is used in nuclear reactors, alloys, and ceramics.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Arabic word 'zargun,' meaning 'gold color.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in zircon and baddeleyite minerals.

elements.name: Niobium
elements.description: Niobium is used in superconductors, aerospace applications, and as an alloying element.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after Niobe, the daughter of Tantalus in Greek mythology.
elements.origin: Primarily found in columbite and tantalite minerals.

elements.name: Molybdenum
elements.description: Molybdenum is used in alloys, electrical contacts, and as a catalyst.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'molybdos,' meaning 'lead-like.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in molybdenite and wulfenite minerals.

elements.name: Technetium
elements.description: Technetium is a radioactive element with limited practical applications, mainly in nuclear medicine.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'technetos,' meaning 'artificial,' as it was the first element to be artificially synthesized.
elements.origin: Primarily produced in nuclear reactors.

elements.name: Ruthenium
elements.description: Ruthenium is used in electronics, jewelry, and as a catalyst.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after 'Ruthenia,' the Latin name for Russia.
elements.origin: Primarily found in pentlandite and laurite ores.

elements.name: Rhodium
elements.description: Rhodium is used in catalytic converters, jewelry, and some electrical contacts.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'rhodon,' meaning 'rose-colored,' due to the color of its compounds.
elements.origin: Primarily found in sperrylite and pentlandite ores.

elements.name: Palladium
elements.description: Palladium is used in catalytic converters, electronics, and dental alloys.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the asteroid Pallas, which was named after the Greek goddess Pallas Athena.
elements.origin: Primarily found in palladium-nickel and copper-nickel ores.

elements.name: Silver
elements.description: Silver is used in jewelry, coins, and various industrial applications.
elements.origin_of_name: Named from the Anglo-Saxon word 'seolfor,' meaning 'silver.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in argentite and horn silver ores.

elements.name: Cadmium
elements.discovered_by: Friedrich Stromeyer, Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann
elements.description: Cadmium is used in batteries, pigments, and as a corrosion-resistant plating.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the asteroid Ceres, which was named after the Roman goddess of agriculture.
elements.origin: Primarily found in greenockite and sphalerite ores.

elements.name: Indium
elements.description: Indium is used in electronics, semiconductors, and as a low-melting-point solder.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Latin word 'indium,' meaning 'indigo,' due to its indigo-blue spectral lines.
elements.origin: Primarily found in zinc ores like sphalerite and iron ores.

elements.name: Tin
elements.description: Tin is used in soldering, coatings, and as an alloying element.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Anglo-Saxon word 'tin,' meaning 'to melt.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in cassiterite and stannite ores.

elements.name: Antimony
elements.description: Antimony is used in flame retardants, batteries, and as a semiconductor.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek words 'anti' and 'monos,' meaning 'not alone' or 'not single,' possibly due to its many compounds.
elements.origin: Primarily found in stibnite and valentinite minerals.

elements.name: Tellurium
elements.description: Tellurium is used in alloys, semiconductors, and some solar cells.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Latin word 'tellus,' meaning 'earth.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in calaverite and sylvanite minerals.

elements.name: Iodine
elements.description: Iodine is used in medicine, photography, and as a dietary supplement.
elements.origin_of_name: Named from the Greek word 'iodes,' meaning 'violet.'
elements.origin: Primarily found in seawater and Chilean caliche deposits.

elements.name: Xenon
elements.description: Xenon is a noble gas used in lighting, lasers, and anesthesia.
elements.origin_of_name: Named from the Greek word 'xenos,' meaning 'strange' or 'foreign.'
elements.origin: Primarily formed through the radioactive decay of isotopes in the Earth's crust.

elements.name: Cesium
elements.description: Cesium is used in atomic clocks, drilling fluids, and as a catalyst.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Latin word 'caesium,' meaning 'sky blue,' due to its spectral lines.
elements.origin: Primarily found in minerals like pollucite and lepidolite.

elements.name: Barium
elements.description: Barium is used in drilling fluids, radiology, and fireworks.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Greek word 'barys,' meaning 'heavy,' due to its high density.
elements.origin: Primarily found in baryte and witherite minerals.

elements.name: Lanthanum
elements.description: Lanthanum is used in alloys, camera lenses, and carbon arc lamps.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek word 'lanthanein,' meaning 'to lie hidden,' as it was initially difficult to separate from other elements.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Cerium
elements.discovered_by: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, Jöns Jakob Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger
elements.description: Cerium is used in catalysts, glass polishing, and as a component in alloys.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the asteroid Ceres, which was named after the Roman goddess of agriculture.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Praseodymium
elements.description: Praseodymium is used in magnets, lighting, and as an alloying element.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek words 'prasios,' meaning 'green,' and 'didymos,' meaning 'twin,' due to the green color of its salts and the element's tendency to form double salts.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Neodymium
elements.description: Neodymium is used in magnets, lasers, and as a colorant in glass.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek words 'neos,' meaning 'new,' and 'didymos,' meaning 'twin,' as it was newly discovered and chemically similar to praseodymium.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Promethium
elements.description: Promethium is radioactive and has limited practical applications, mainly in nuclear batteries.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the Titan Prometheus from Greek mythology, who stole fire from the gods.
elements.origin: Primarily produced in nuclear reactors.

elements.name: Samarium
elements.description: Samarium is used in magnets, catalysts, and as a neutron absorber in nuclear reactors.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the mineral samarskite, which was named after Vasili Samarsky-Bykhovets, a Russian mining official.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Europium
elements.description: Europium is used in phosphors, Euro banknotes, and nuclear reactor control rods.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the continent of Europe.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Gadolinium
elements.description: Gadolinium is used in MRI contrast agents, nuclear reactors, and electronics.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after Johan Gadolin, a Finnish chemist.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Terbium
elements.description: Terbium is used in phosphors, fuel cells, and as a dopant in solid-state devices.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden, where the mineral yttria (containing yttrium) was discovered.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Dysprosium
elements.description: Dysprosium is used in high-strength magnets, lighting, and as a neutron absorber.
elements.origin_of_name: Derived from the Greek words 'dysprositos,' meaning 'hard to get,' due to its scarcity and difficulty of separation from other elements.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Holmium
elements.description: Holmium is used in lasers, nuclear control rods, and some medical applications.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after Stockholm, Sweden, where it was discovered.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Erbium
elements.description: Erbium is used in fiber optics, lasers, and as a colorant in glass and ceramics.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden, where the mineral yttria (containing yttrium) was discovered.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Thulium
elements.description: Thulium is used in portable X-ray machines, lasers, and as a dopant in crystals.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after Thule, a mythical island in the far north, by its discoverer Per Theodor Cleve.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and bastnäsite minerals.

elements.name: Ytterbium
elements.description: Ytterbium is used in lasers, nuclear medicine, and as a doping agent in stainless steel.
elements.origin_of_name: Named after the village of Ytterby in Sweden, where the mineral yttria (containing yttrium) was discovered.
elements.origin: Primarily found in monazite and xenotime minerals.
